VOL. XX, NO. 5.
HOPKINS DEFEATS GETTYSBURG
IN FASTEST CONTEST OF SEASON

r
BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 8, 194.

SNAPPED AT THE SWARTHMORE GAME

Hoffman's Drop Kicks a Feature — Wilkinson, Brooks
and Bowers also Star.

(Continued on page 8, col. 3)

ELEVEN SHOWS BIG IMPROVEMENT IN ALL DEPARTMENTS
Work of Black and Blue in Saturday's
Contest Better Than That of First
Games —Team Shows Ability to
Fight Under Pressure, but
Lacks Good Interference.

Black and Blue Gridiron Warriors Put
Up Splendid Fight, and Win 23 to 7.

Outplaying her opponents from
start to finish, Hopkins' well-balanced 'football team defeated the
strorig Gettysburg- eleven-at Homewood on Saturday, 23 to 7. HOffman kicked three field goals for
the Black and Blue, the boots coming at time's when Hopkins needed
the Points; while Brooks displayed
an aggressiveness on both the offensive and defensive, w h i cli
marked him as the star of the contest.
It was probably the best showing made by the team, as a whole,
SO far this season. Although
the lineup was somewhat changed,
the Black and Blue eleven played
as a unit, breaking up the plays
of Gettysburg at will. In this respect, Leibensperger and Wilkinson played their usual strong game,
While the work of Schmidt and
.Gorman showed material improvement.
The game started promptly at
3 P. M. The weather was ideal in
every respect and a large crowd
was on hand. Several hundred
Gettysburg rooters with an improvised band occupied the west
stand and helped to make things
lively.
Neither team scored during the
first quarter, the ball remaining for
the most part in the middle of the
field, with both sides punting frequently. However, it was during
this period that Hoffman made his
first attempt at a field goal. The
Pass from the center was high and
Bobby was forced to get the ball off
quickly, with the result that it
missed the uprights by a few inches.
In the second quarter, Hoffman
made two successful kicks. The
first goal was probably the most
h air-raising feature of the game.
After Gettysburg had lost the ball
On downs,
Hopkins advanced to the,
visitors' 40-yard line, due to the
Splendid work of Brooks and Bowers. Hoffman then made his first
score. The pass was again high
and the ball was necessarily kicked
quickly. It struck the right-hand
Upright, bounded back to the crossbar and finally flopped over, much
to the joy of Hopkins rooters.
Two minutes later, Hoffman rePeated his performance from GettYsburg's 35-yard line—this time
the ball going over cleanly. The
half ended with the score: Hopkins,
6; Gettysburg, o.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

By COACH CHARLES E. BRICKLEY

The Juniors proved at Homewood last Friday that they had not
been over bold in their sweeping
challenge to the combined forces of
the rest of the University, when
they overwhelmed their opponents
to the tune of 56 to 16. The meet
had to be postponed from Wednesday to Friday on account of the
cold weather, and when it did take
place many of those who had signified their intention of taking part
were detained in laboratories and
by other engagements, so that the
number of contestants was not as
large as had been expected. There
were, however, enough entries in
every event to make good contests,
and the primary purpose of the
meet—to bring out the ability of
the various men early in the year—
was successfully accomplished.
The meet formed a fitting conclusion to the outdoor fall practice,
which has been carried on upon a
much larger scale this year than
ever before at Hopkins, and it is
the idea of those who proposed
the plan to have a fall track meet
become an annual affair and build
it up to become a much more hotly
contested affair in years to come.
There is no question as to the advantage of fall work in building
up athletes, and a meet as a conclusion to the practices forms a goal
to work toward.
The squad will now enjoy a rest
until work begins in the cage early
in December, With the exception
of the cross-country men. This
part of the squad is whipping itself into shape for the annual cross-

"Municipal Problems" was the
subject of the lecture delivered last
Thursday afternoon by President
Frank J. Goodnow before an unusually large audience at the Academy of Music. The lecture was
the first of a series to be delivered
by noted men, arranged by the
Women's Civic League and the
Municipal Art Society, acting with
the University.
Mayor Preston presided and, on
introducing Dr. Goodnow, he spoke
appreciatively of the advantage to
the community in having such an authority upon governmental and administrative problems in the city,
who is taking such an active interest in its development and progress.
President Goodnow began his lecture by expressing his hesitancy in
speaking before the Mayor, who had
had practical experience in city government, while he could only offer
an academic study of the development and problems of municipal
government. Until Napoleon III
and Baron Hausman undertook
the improvement of Paris little had
been done, he said, in bettering municipal conditions, but that example
was followed swiftly by both Great
Britain and Germany, so that by the
end of the nineteenth century a
transformation had been wrought
in the cities of Europe. Dr. Albert
Shaw, a graduate of Hopkins, was
the first to direct the attention of
the American people to the municipal problem.

Showing a decided improvement
in almost every department of play,
Hopkins was able to defeat Gettysburg 23 to 7 on Saturday last.
Although the latter team was without the services of one or two of
her best men, the visitors presented
a strongly-balanced team, which
played intelligent football throughout.
The value of the kicking game
was shown Saturday, for it was
mainly through the superior punting game on the part of Hopkins
that the ball was placed within scoring distance, and once a fumbled
punt was converted into a Hopkins'
touchdown.
Hopkins showed a pleasing tendency to follow the ball on Saturday, a feature which was lacking
a week ago. A team which follows the ball well is bound to get
most of the breaks in its favor
sooner or later.
Perhaps the weakest department
of Hopkins play was the interference, or better, the lack of it. The
Hopkins men do not seem to want
to leave their feet to dive at an
opponent in order to take him out
of the play. Good interference is
one of the fundamental essentials of
football and the Hopkins team, as
a whole, must learn to do it much
better if we are to get successful
results in these last three games.
Outside of the punting, the offensive strength of the two teams
was very nearly equal. Hopkins was
stronger on defense, but not so
much more so as to tell very heavily
in its favor. The equality of the
two teams made the result of the
game a question of which team
would break under the strain. At
the beginning of the second half it
looked as if Hopkins had broken
when Gettysburg ran back a punt
for a touchdown, the kicked goal
from which put them ahead, 7 to 6.
But this setback seemed to be just
the stimulus that the Hopkins team
needed, for from that time on their
play improved steadily until in the
fourth quarter; when the team
showed its best football of the year.
Saturday's contest proved that
the Hopkins team could fight, that
they could play under pressure and
that they could come from behind
and win. It also showed the value
of good substitutes, for without them
Hopkins couldn't have won the
game.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 8, 1915.

DEBATERS REJECT CHALLENGES JUNIORS MEET AT HOMEWOOD
Offers From Four Universities in South
Refused as Matter of Policy—Triangular Arrangement to Be Made.

First Class Meeting Held in New Buildings—Hullabaloo Staff Elected—Engineering Society Elects-Officers.

That Hopkins' debaters are winning a nation-wide reputation is
shown by the fact that at its last
meeting the Debating Council was
forced to reject challenges from
four universities, several of whom
have three and four times as large
an enrollment of students as has
Hopkins.
These challenges were received
from Washington and Lee University, Catholic University, George
Washington University and Tulane University. It is with sincere regret that the Council declined contests with these institutions, but the policy of holding only
two debates a year, and those in
the triangular league with North
Carolina and Virginia, has been so
successful in the past that it was
thought to be unwise to undertake
any new contests, however attractive they might seem.
Negotiations with North Carolina and Virginia with reference to
the continuance of the league has
already been begun, although there
is practically no doubt that the
three-sided contest will take place
this year, and that the arrangement
of last year, to all intents and purposes, will remain unchanged.
However, if any unforeseen reason should prevent the league from
being formed this year, Hopkins
would have no trouble in arranging
debates with any of the universities
from whom it has received challenges. It is probable that if it were
to become necessary to change the
debating schedule, the choice of antagonists would fall either upon
Washington and Lee, with whom
Hopkins has enjoyed cordial relations in the past, or upon the New
Orleans institution.
The Council has organized for
the year with Mr. Harrison Coffin, '16, as president, and Mr.
Alexander Steinbach, '17, as secretary. A committee consisting of
Mr. Weech, '17, chairman; Mr.
Tingley, '16; and Mr. Oppenheimer, '18, has been appointed to
choose a subject for Hopkins to
submit to North Carolina and
Virginia.
The date of the inter-class debate for this year has been set for
January 28, and efforts will be
made to hold the triangular debate on or near April 1. In this
way the two will not conflict and
abundant time will be allowed for
preparation.
Another proof of the growth of
Hopkins' reputation in debate is
the fact that it has been prominently mentioned in the last Intercollegiate Debate Book. Its record
of two consecutive victories over
both its opponents is alluded to,
and the agreement between North
Carolina, Virginia and Hopkins is
given in full.

The Junior Class meeting, which
was held at Homewood last Tuesday afternoon, was the first class
meeting that had ever been held
at Homewood. The juniors will
continue to have their class meetings at Homewood, as a motion to
this effect was passed at the first
meeting of the 1917 Class this year.
The first part of the meeting was
devoted to the election of the
junior officers of the Engineering
Society. The seniors elect the
president and the treasurer of the
society, while the juniors elect the
vice-president and the secretary.
Thompson was elected vice-president and Binford was chosen as
secretary.
The committee which was appointed to make nominations for
the Hullabaloo Board nominated
thirty men. Twelve men were
elected to the board, no specifications being made as to the particular positions they are to hold. The
men elected will meet shortly and
choose an editor-in-chief, a business manager and men for the other
positions on the board. The twelve
elected were Binford, Thompson,
Defandorf, Straus, Stuart, Baker,
Hall, Paul Sutton, Weech, Fulton,
Boyce and Owings.
Mr. Tingley, editor-in-chief of
the 1916 Hullabaloo, then addressed
the meeting. He said that this
year's class-book was going to be
better and more original than any
Hullabaloo that had ever been published and that he hoped the 1917
book would be even better. He
concluded his address by asking all
the juniors to buy a copy of the
1916 Hullabaloo.
After President Stuart appointed
a committee consisting of Boyce
(chairman), Straus and Thompson
to get up a good class flag, the
meeting adjourned.

CALIFORNIANS VISIT CITY
Accompanied by Hopkins Committee,
Prize-winning Farmer Boys From
Golden State Spend Day in
Baltimore.

Accompanied by Mr. J. Collin
Vincent, of the Baltimore Chamber
of Commerce, and by a committee of four Hopkins undergraduates, twenty-nine agricultural students from California spent last
Thursday in seeing points of interest in and about Baltimore, in
inspecting the farming country of
the Green Spring Valley and in
visiting the Sparks Agricultural
School of Sparks, Md. The California men, who are all prize winners in an agricultural contest held
annually in their State, are engaged
in a month's tour of the East and
came to Baltimore directly from
New York.
The Hopkins committee which
helped to entertain the visitors consisted of E. M. Spieker, C. H.
Tinges, M. E. Bagley and T. J.
Tingley, all of the Senior Class.
The party first took a short trip
about the harbor in the city tug
Baltimore and visited the Chamber
of Commerce, Custom House and
the Mayor's office. A motor trip
was then taken to Brooklandwood
Dairy Farm in the Green Spring
Valley and from thence to the agricultural school at Sparks. After
luncheon had been served at the
latter institution by the members
of the domestic science class, a
basket-ball game took place between
the visitors and the team of the
Maryland school, the California
men being defeated by a rather
startling score. The motor trip
back to Baltimore, dinner at the
City Club and an entertainment
given by the Californians ended a
somewhat exhausting but thoroughly pleasurable day.
President Goodnow, who was a
speaker at the dinner given to the
prize winners of last year, was unable to be present at the City Club
on Thursday evening. The University, however, presented each of

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 8, 1915.
LARGE NUMBER OF HOPKINS MEN
AT HARVARD LAW SCHOOL

The number of Hopkins men at
the Harvard Law School is unusually large this year. Three members of last year's graduating class
alone are registered at the Harvard
institution, viz.: Messrs. John S.
Short, Avra Warren and Millard
Eiseman. Mr. Short, as will be remembered, was editor-in-chief of
THE NEWS-LETTER and of the 1915
Hullabaloo.
Another well - known alumnus
who has just entered the Harvard
Law School this year is Mr. Leslie
Buckler, who was graduated from
Hopkins in the Class of 1912 and
who received the degree of master
of arts two years later. Until
leaving for Harvard, Mr. Buckler
was associated with the law firm of
Venable, Baetjer & Howard.
Mr. Dushane Penniman, A. B.
13, is now a second-year student
at the law school, having passed his
first year examinations with great
credit.
At least ten undergraduates have
signified their intention of going
to Harvard after their graduation
from Hopkins.

The executive- committee of the
Johns Hopkins University, at a
meeting presided over by President
Frank J. Goodnow, approved a
resolution offered by the Alumni
Association that military training
be inaugurated in the institution.
In compliance with the purport of
the resolution, the committee adopted a recommendation that a special
committee be appointed by the
Board of Trustees to investigate
the project.
Unless objection to the plan develops, a committee will be named
to ascertain in what way the University can include in its curriculum
an elementary course in military instruction without burdening the
student body with too much work.
Before definite plans can be decided upon, the members of the
faculty will have to confer, for

Nothing is more indicative of University spirit than the •interest the
men take in the team or teams; and
nothing shows this interest quite
so clearly as the way they support
them in the "rooting section." During the Swarthmore game, and
especially through the last 'disheartening minutes, the fellows cheered
the team with all they had in them.
One cannot help feeling that there
has been a rebirth of the old Hopkins spirit. Two sections of rooters is a new thing, but more encouraging still is the fact that both
the men on the team and the men
in the stands have a determination
to see the game through and to
fight to the end. Though some of
the new men do not as yet know
the songs, they have been sung
pretty well;'and the yelling has
been remarkably good these last
few weeks. It might be suggested,
however, that instead of singing
some of our "ancient" rag-time
songs, the cheer leader try out one
of those good Hopkins songs-like
Stollenwerck's or "We're Here to
Win Again, Hopkins." They are
distinctively our own and the music has a new sound to the bystanders. But better than the song
or yell is the way in which it is
given. Ragged and half-hearted
cheering would ruin- the best yell.
This We have not had. The cheering
at Homewood bas been snappy and
the spirit has not lagged even during the close of the last period. It
is this encouragement which will
often urge a tired team to a successful effort in a rather discouraging position. The fellows must

AT OTHER COLLEGES
A new idea in college newspaper
circulation has been introduced at
Lafayette College. Lafayette, the
student publication, is now provided
to each student as part of the benefit of a new "student activity fee,"
which is collected by the college.
* * *
At the University of Washington
chimes a-re used to announce the
result of football games played
away from home. If the 'Varsity
is victorious, the university "Alma
Mater" is played, followed by the
score, which is tolled out on two
bells-Washington's score coming
first on a low-toned bell and the
score of the opponents following on
a bell of higher pitch. If the team
meets defeat,"Home, Sweet Home"
is rendered by the chime ringer.
* * *
Students at Dartmouth have cleverly evaded the ruling of the Interstate Commerce Commission which
threatened to prevent them from
going to football games as "live
stock" in freight cars. They put a
pig in each car and the students go
along as caretakers.
* * *
Mr. Fritz Kellerman, a former
profeSsor at the University of Kansas, has been given the iron cross
for bravery in battle at BrestLitowsk, Russia.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 8, 1915.
WHO'S WHO IN FOOTBALL

A List of Players on This Year's Squad,
With Short Biography of Each
Man's Football Experience.

The University is fortunate this
year in having a large number of
experienced football men on the
squad. The following is a list of
the members of the squad, with
their positions and experience:
Aubrey comes from the University of Texas, where he played
guard for two years.
Barclay has played a guard position at Hopkins for three years and
is considered one of the best men in
the State at this position.
Bagley played in the backfield at
Tome School and has played for
two years at Hopkins.
Benson is playing his first year
of football.
Bowers was quarterback on the
Western Maryland team for two
years and has played one year at
Hopkins, making the all-Maryland
team.
Joe Branham played in the backfield on the Washington College
team before coming to Hopkins last
year.
Jack Branham has had three
years' experience as a Hopkins
halfback.
Brooks has played one year at
Hopkins.
Brumbaugh comes from Western
Maryland, where he played two
years.
Connolly conies from Towson
High School and played on last
year's freshman team.
Cort played last year on the
freshman team.
Cox is an experienced man, coming from the Shenandoah Military
Institute.
R. Cox played at fullback position on the Baltimore City College
team.
Darley has had a year of quarterback experience at Hopkins.
Duncan was a backfield man on
last year's freshman team, coming
from Towson High School.
Ellicott had two years' experience as a back on Gilman School's
team.
F. Ewing played last year at
Hopkins in an end position.
L. Ewing has never played before this season.
Elmendorf was Rutger's captain
and quarterback last year, being a
second all-American choice.
Finney was a member of Princeton's football squad for two years,
playing end.
Frank has had Hopkins experience for two years.
Frock was a substitute halfback
on Michigan's team last year.
Fulton played on the City College eleven for two years and on
Hopkins for one year.
Gorman's experience at the game
is the same as Fulton's.
Golden is a candidate for a
guard position, having played on
last year's freshman team.

Hall has had two year's experience on the Hopkins squad.
Hoffman played last year in the
fullback position at Hopkins, being
an all-Maryland choice.
Kauffman is an experienced
guard from Franklin and Marshall.
Kefover is a heavy man from St.
James' School, where he played
three years.
Kirk was end on last year's
Marston's team.
Martindale is going through his
first year at football.
Ormond was center on Princeton
for two years and is a fast, aggressive man.
Captain Primrose played at City
College and has been 'Varsity center at Hopkins for three years.
Randall had two years of football at Gilman and one at Hopkins.
Richards has had a year's experience at Hopkins.
Sachs is an experienced back
from Gettysburg College.
Schmidt was Polytechnic's mainstay in the line last year.
Smith is a new man at the
game.
Sonneborn is a big man from last
year's Park School team.
Stanley has had two years' experience at Dunham's.
Strom never played before, but
is rapidly developing.
Prince also has never played before.
Uhler has been a regular backfield man at Hopkins for three
years. He played at City College.
Webb has played three years at
Jefferson School.
Wessels is having his first try
at football.
Wilkinson was last year's captain
and has been the backbone of the
line for the past two years.
Woodward has had one year of
experience at City College and one
at Hopkins.
Yewell played for two years at
Dunham's and was one of last
year's regular guards.

Coach Brickley a Shot-Putter.

Although it is not generally
known, Coach Brickley has been
something of a shot-putter in his
day. He walked over to the pit
where several Hopkins men were
throwing the twelve-pound shot one
afternoon not long ago and surprised everyone by picking up a
twelve pounder and, with no apparent effort, throwing it nearly
forty-five feet. He further surprised everyone by saying that his
record for the sixteen-pound shot
was forty-four feet, which beats
the Hopkins record. He made several creditable throws with a sixteen pounder before returning to
his football team.

Freshman Bible Class Organizes.

The Freshman Bible Study Class
held its first meeting last Tuesday.
C. P. McCormick was chosen president and R. C. Thomsen, secretary.
The class, which will take up the
course of "Student Standards of
Action," will meet every Tuesday
at i P. M. and will be led by Mr.
J. W. Moore. All freshmen are
invited.

"X. Y. Z." Defends Freshmen.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LErrER :

UNIVERSITY DIRECTORY

Sir—I wish to disagree with the
sentiments expressed by "i8" in
his letter published in last week's
NEWS - LETTER. The sophomore
who wrote it seems to consider the
Freshman Class a mob of unruly
"toughs," who can only be tamed
by the most severe hazing tactics.
I think the rest of the school will
agree with me that the freshmen
are not of this type, but are sensible enough to see the value of
the regulations and to obey them.
If some first-year man inadvertently
neglected to remove his hat on first
entering McCoy Hall or broke the
rules in some other trifling way,
the sophomore who raved so in
last week's NEWS-LETTER apparently took it that the whole '19
Class was deliberately defying the
rules and challenging the sophomores to a free-for-all.
Such is not the case. If the
sophomores will keep their heads
they will see that the freshmen are
doing all in their power toward
making the plan of having freshman regulations a success.
The rules were a new thing to
the freshmen and any slight infringements should be overlooked
at first. The Class of '18 should
not abandon the plans for a peaceful settlement of the differences between the first and second years,
nor should they lose confidence in
the ability of the Student Council
to handle the affair in the best way,
both for the students and the University. The freshmen are doing
their part; let the sophomores remember what their part really is
and not do otherwise.
X. Y. Z.
November 6, 1915.

ANNAPOLIS SHORT LINE

The municipal problem is not only
modern, but is in a large degree
peculiar to each city. "The peculiarity depends upon the general social and economic conditions of the
country in which the city is located; upon the geographical position of the city; upon the population and local conditions of the
city. No attempt to solve the problems of a particular city," Dr.
Goodnow continued, "which does
not take into account its peculiar
conditions will be successful. Many
suggestions May be- derived from
a consideration of the conditions
of other cities, but any attempt to
adopt in a wholesale manner ,instir
tutions which have met with success under other conditions is liable
to be followed by a very small
measure of success or even by positive failure."
Dr. Goodnow next discussed the
evolution of the form of municipal
government during the last century.
He told of the original council system, adopted from England but
modified by universal suffrage,
where the council was elected, and
the mayor also, unless appointed by
the governor. Its development into
the board system was traced, with
its dissipation of responsibility and
denial of popular control. Later
there came, said Dr. Goodnow, the
period in which the power of the
mayor was expanded greatly, which
tended toward a larger concentration of power. The main objection to the "mayor system" is its
tendency to dislocate the entire municipal government at every mayoralty election.
The most recent form of city
government is that which lodges the
power in a commission of five elected
members, each of whom has under.
his control some particular branch of
the administration. Substantially,
this is the old "council system." It
is significant, Dr. Goodnow observed, that after a century of
change America should return to
the council system, 'to which Great
Britain has adhered all the while
with success. "Good city government," Dr. Goodnow concluded,
"will result from the successful
adaptation of municipal institutions
to local conditions."

The artist was painting—sunset,
red, with blue streaks and green
dots. The old rustic, at a respectful distance, was watching.
"Ah," said the artist, looking up
suddenly, "perhaps to you, too, nature has opened her sky-pictures
page by page? Have you seen the
lambent flame of dawn leaping
across the livid East; the redstained, sulphurous islets floating iri
the lake of fire in the West; the
ragged clouds at midnight, black as
raven's wing, blotting out the shuddering moon?"
"No," replied the rustic shortly,
"not since I signed the pledge."

second half came Gettysburg's lone
touchdown. Rowe caught a punt
on his own 45-yard line and by
clever dodging carried the ball fiftyfive Tards for a touchdown. Stoney
kicked goal.

depressed with the score against
them. However, it was shortly
after this that Hoffman kicked his
third field goal, making the score
9 to 7 in favor of Hopkins.
In the fourth quarter Gettysburg proved easy, Hopkins scoring
two touchdowns during that period.
The first was due to the excellent
line plunging of Brooks and the
headwork of Bowers, while the second was made by Eggie Gorman,
who recovered a punt which Rowe
fumbled on his own 3-yard line.
Wilkinson kicked goal on both occasions.

HOPKINS DEFEATS GETTYSBURG
IN FASTEST CONTEST OF SEASON

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 8, 194.

SNAPPED AT THE SWARTHMORE GAME

Hoffman's Drop Kicks a Feature — Wilkinson, Brooks
and Bowers also Star.

(Continued on page 8, col. 3)

ELEVEN SHOWS BIG IMPROVEMENT IN ALL DEPARTMENTS
Work of Black and Blue in Saturday's
Contest Better Than That of First
Games —Team Shows Ability to
Fight Under Pressure, but
Lacks Good Interference.

Black and Blue Gridiron Warriors Put
Up Splendid Fight, and Win 23 to 7.

Outplaying her opponents from
start to finish, Hopkins' well-balanced 'football team defeated the
strorig Gettysburg- eleven-at Homewood on Saturday, 23 to 7. HOffman kicked three field goals for
the Black and Blue, the boots coming at time's when Hopkins needed
the Points; while Brooks displayed
an aggressiveness on both the offensive and defensive, w h i cli
marked him as the star of the contest.
It was probably the best showing made by the team, as a whole,
SO far this season. Although
the lineup was somewhat changed,
the Black and Blue eleven played
as a unit, breaking up the plays
of Gettysburg at will. In this respect, Leibensperger and Wilkinson played their usual strong game,
While the work of Schmidt and
.Gorman showed material improvement.
The game started promptly at
3 P. M. The weather was ideal in
every respect and a large crowd
was on hand. Several hundred
Gettysburg rooters with an improvised band occupied the west
stand and helped to make things
lively.
Neither team scored during the
first quarter, the ball remaining for
the most part in the middle of the
field, with both sides punting frequently. However, it was during
this period that Hoffman made his
first attempt at a field goal. The
Pass from the center was high and
Bobby was forced to get the ball off
quickly, with the result that it
missed the uprights by a few inches.
In the second quarter, Hoffman
made two successful kicks. The
first goal was probably the most
h air-raising feature of the game.
After Gettysburg had lost the ball
On downs,
Hopkins advanced to the,
visitors' 40-yard line, due to the
Splendid work of Brooks and Bowers. Hoffman then made his first
score. The pass was again high
and the ball was necessarily kicked
quickly. It struck the right-hand
Upright, bounded back to the crossbar and finally flopped over, much
to the joy of Hopkins rooters.
Two minutes later, Hoffman rePeated his performance from GettYsburg's 35-yard line—this time
the ball going over cleanly. The
half ended with the score: Hopkins,
6; Gettysburg, o.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

By COACH CHARLES E. BRICKLEY

The Juniors proved at Homewood last Friday that they had not
been over bold in their sweeping
challenge to the combined forces of
the rest of the University, when
they overwhelmed their opponents
to the tune of 56 to 16. The meet
had to be postponed from Wednesday to Friday on account of the
cold weather, and when it did take
place many of those who had signified their intention of taking part
were detained in laboratories and
by other engagements, so that the
number of contestants was not as
large as had been expected. There
were, however, enough entries in
every event to make good contests,
and the primary purpose of the
meet—to bring out the ability of
the various men early in the year—
was successfully accomplished.
The meet formed a fitting conclusion to the outdoor fall practice,
which has been carried on upon a
much larger scale this year than
ever before at Hopkins, and it is
the idea of those who proposed
the plan to have a fall track meet
become an annual affair and build
it up to become a much more hotly
contested affair in years to come.
There is no question as to the advantage of fall work in building
up athletes, and a meet as a conclusion to the practices forms a goal
to work toward.
The squad will now enjoy a rest
until work begins in the cage early
in December, With the exception
of the cross-country men. This
part of the squad is whipping itself into shape for the annual cross-

"Municipal Problems" was the
subject of the lecture delivered last
Thursday afternoon by President
Frank J. Goodnow before an unusually large audience at the Academy of Music. The lecture was
the first of a series to be delivered
by noted men, arranged by the
Women's Civic League and the
Municipal Art Society, acting with
the University.
Mayor Preston presided and, on
introducing Dr. Goodnow, he spoke
appreciatively of the advantage to
the community in having such an authority upon governmental and administrative problems in the city,
who is taking such an active interest in its development and progress.
President Goodnow began his lecture by expressing his hesitancy in
speaking before the Mayor, who had
had practical experience in city government, while he could only offer
an academic study of the development and problems of municipal
government. Until Napoleon III
and Baron Hausman undertook
the improvement of Paris little had
been done, he said, in bettering municipal conditions, but that example
was followed swiftly by both Great
Britain and Germany, so that by the
end of the nineteenth century a
transformation had been wrought
in the cities of Europe. Dr. Albert
Shaw, a graduate of Hopkins, was
the first to direct the attention of
the American people to the municipal problem.

Showing a decided improvement
in almost every department of play,
Hopkins was able to defeat Gettysburg 23 to 7 on Saturday last.
Although the latter team was without the services of one or two of
her best men, the visitors presented
a strongly-balanced team, which
played intelligent football throughout.
The value of the kicking game
was shown Saturday, for it was
mainly through the superior punting game on the part of Hopkins
that the ball was placed within scoring distance, and once a fumbled
punt was converted into a Hopkins'
touchdown.
Hopkins showed a pleasing tendency to follow the ball on Saturday, a feature which was lacking
a week ago. A team which follows the ball well is bound to get
most of the breaks in its favor
sooner or later.
Perhaps the weakest department
of Hopkins play was the interference, or better, the lack of it. The
Hopkins men do not seem to want
to leave their feet to dive at an
opponent in order to take him out
of the play. Good interference is
one of the fundamental essentials of
football and the Hopkins team, as
a whole, must learn to do it much
better if we are to get successful
results in these last three games.
Outside of the punting, the offensive strength of the two teams
was very nearly equal. Hopkins was
stronger on defense, but not so
much more so as to tell very heavily
in its favor. The equality of the
two teams made the result of the
game a question of which team
would break under the strain. At
the beginning of the second half it
looked as if Hopkins had broken
when Gettysburg ran back a punt
for a touchdown, the kicked goal
from which put them ahead, 7 to 6.
But this setback seemed to be just
the stimulus that the Hopkins team
needed, for from that time on their
play improved steadily until in the
fourth quarter; when the team
showed its best football of the year.
Saturday's contest proved that
the Hopkins team could fight, that
they could play under pressure and
that they could come from behind
and win. It also showed the value
of good substitutes, for without them
Hopkins couldn't have won the
game.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 8, 1915.

DEBATERS REJECT CHALLENGES JUNIORS MEET AT HOMEWOOD
Offers From Four Universities in South
Refused as Matter of Policy—Triangular Arrangement to Be Made.

First Class Meeting Held in New Buildings—Hullabaloo Staff Elected—Engineering Society Elects-Officers.

That Hopkins' debaters are winning a nation-wide reputation is
shown by the fact that at its last
meeting the Debating Council was
forced to reject challenges from
four universities, several of whom
have three and four times as large
an enrollment of students as has
Hopkins.
These challenges were received
from Washington and Lee University, Catholic University, George
Washington University and Tulane University. It is with sincere regret that the Council declined contests with these institutions, but the policy of holding only
two debates a year, and those in
the triangular league with North
Carolina and Virginia, has been so
successful in the past that it was
thought to be unwise to undertake
any new contests, however attractive they might seem.
Negotiations with North Carolina and Virginia with reference to
the continuance of the league has
already been begun, although there
is practically no doubt that the
three-sided contest will take place
this year, and that the arrangement
of last year, to all intents and purposes, will remain unchanged.
However, if any unforeseen reason should prevent the league from
being formed this year, Hopkins
would have no trouble in arranging
debates with any of the universities
from whom it has received challenges. It is probable that if it were
to become necessary to change the
debating schedule, the choice of antagonists would fall either upon
Washington and Lee, with whom
Hopkins has enjoyed cordial relations in the past, or upon the New
Orleans institution.
The Council has organized for
the year with Mr. Harrison Coffin, '16, as president, and Mr.
Alexander Steinbach, '17, as secretary. A committee consisting of
Mr. Weech, '17, chairman; Mr.
Tingley, '16; and Mr. Oppenheimer, '18, has been appointed to
choose a subject for Hopkins to
submit to North Carolina and
Virginia.
The date of the inter-class debate for this year has been set for
January 28, and efforts will be
made to hold the triangular debate on or near April 1. In this
way the two will not conflict and
abundant time will be allowed for
preparation.
Another proof of the growth of
Hopkins' reputation in debate is
the fact that it has been prominently mentioned in the last Intercollegiate Debate Book. Its record
of two consecutive victories over
both its opponents is alluded to,
and the agreement between North
Carolina, Virginia and Hopkins is
given in full.

The Junior Class meeting, which
was held at Homewood last Tuesday afternoon, was the first class
meeting that had ever been held
at Homewood. The juniors will
continue to have their class meetings at Homewood, as a motion to
this effect was passed at the first
meeting of the 1917 Class this year.
The first part of the meeting was
devoted to the election of the
junior officers of the Engineering
Society. The seniors elect the
president and the treasurer of the
society, while the juniors elect the
vice-president and the secretary.
Thompson was elected vice-president and Binford was chosen as
secretary.
The committee which was appointed to make nominations for
the Hullabaloo Board nominated
thirty men. Twelve men were
elected to the board, no specifications being made as to the particular positions they are to hold. The
men elected will meet shortly and
choose an editor-in-chief, a business manager and men for the other
positions on the board. The twelve
elected were Binford, Thompson,
Defandorf, Straus, Stuart, Baker,
Hall, Paul Sutton, Weech, Fulton,
Boyce and Owings.
Mr. Tingley, editor-in-chief of
the 1916 Hullabaloo, then addressed
the meeting. He said that this
year's class-book was going to be
better and more original than any
Hullabaloo that had ever been published and that he hoped the 1917
book would be even better. He
concluded his address by asking all
the juniors to buy a copy of the
1916 Hullabaloo.
After President Stuart appointed
a committee consisting of Boyce
(chairman), Straus and Thompson
to get up a good class flag, the
meeting adjourned.

CALIFORNIANS VISIT CITY
Accompanied by Hopkins Committee,
Prize-winning Farmer Boys From
Golden State Spend Day in
Baltimore.

Accompanied by Mr. J. Collin
Vincent, of the Baltimore Chamber
of Commerce, and by a committee of four Hopkins undergraduates, twenty-nine agricultural students from California spent last
Thursday in seeing points of interest in and about Baltimore, in
inspecting the farming country of
the Green Spring Valley and in
visiting the Sparks Agricultural
School of Sparks, Md. The California men, who are all prize winners in an agricultural contest held
annually in their State, are engaged
in a month's tour of the East and
came to Baltimore directly from
New York.
The Hopkins committee which
helped to entertain the visitors consisted of E. M. Spieker, C. H.
Tinges, M. E. Bagley and T. J.
Tingley, all of the Senior Class.
The party first took a short trip
about the harbor in the city tug
Baltimore and visited the Chamber
of Commerce, Custom House and
the Mayor's office. A motor trip
was then taken to Brooklandwood
Dairy Farm in the Green Spring
Valley and from thence to the agricultural school at Sparks. After
luncheon had been served at the
latter institution by the members
of the domestic science class, a
basket-ball game took place between
the visitors and the team of the
Maryland school, the California
men being defeated by a rather
startling score. The motor trip
back to Baltimore, dinner at the
City Club and an entertainment
given by the Californians ended a
somewhat exhausting but thoroughly pleasurable day.
President Goodnow, who was a
speaker at the dinner given to the
prize winners of last year, was unable to be present at the City Club
on Thursday evening. The University, however, presented each of

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 8, 1915.
LARGE NUMBER OF HOPKINS MEN
AT HARVARD LAW SCHOOL

The number of Hopkins men at
the Harvard Law School is unusually large this year. Three members of last year's graduating class
alone are registered at the Harvard
institution, viz.: Messrs. John S.
Short, Avra Warren and Millard
Eiseman. Mr. Short, as will be remembered, was editor-in-chief of
THE NEWS-LETTER and of the 1915
Hullabaloo.
Another well - known alumnus
who has just entered the Harvard
Law School this year is Mr. Leslie
Buckler, who was graduated from
Hopkins in the Class of 1912 and
who received the degree of master
of arts two years later. Until
leaving for Harvard, Mr. Buckler
was associated with the law firm of
Venable, Baetjer & Howard.
Mr. Dushane Penniman, A. B.
13, is now a second-year student
at the law school, having passed his
first year examinations with great
credit.
At least ten undergraduates have
signified their intention of going
to Harvard after their graduation
from Hopkins.

Nothing is more indicative of University spirit than the •interest the
men take in the team or teams; and
nothing shows this interest quite
so clearly as the way they support
them in the "rooting section." During the Swarthmore game, and
especially through the last 'disheartening minutes, the fellows cheered
the team with all they had in them.
One cannot help feeling that there
has been a rebirth of the old Hopkins spirit. Two sections of rooters is a new thing, but more encouraging still is the fact that both
the men on the team and the men
in the stands have a determination
to see the game through and to
fight to the end. Though some of
the new men do not as yet know
the songs, they have been sung
pretty well;'and the yelling has
been remarkably good these last
few weeks. It might be suggested,
however, that instead of singing
some of our "ancient" rag-time
songs, the cheer leader try out one
of those good Hopkins songs-like
Stollenwerck's or "We're Here to
Win Again, Hopkins." They are
distinctively our own and the music has a new sound to the bystanders. But better than the song
or yell is the way in which it is
given. Ragged and half-hearted
cheering would ruin- the best yell.
This We have not had. The cheering
at Homewood bas been snappy and
the spirit has not lagged even during the close of the last period. It
is this encouragement which will
often urge a tired team to a successful effort in a rather discouraging position. The fellows must

AT OTHER COLLEGES
A new idea in college newspaper
circulation has been introduced at
Lafayette College. Lafayette, the
student publication, is now provided
to each student as part of the benefit of a new "student activity fee,"
which is collected by the college.
* * *
At the University of Washington
chimes a-re used to announce the
result of football games played
away from home. If the 'Varsity
is victorious, the university "Alma
Mater" is played, followed by the
score, which is tolled out on two
bells-Washington's score coming
first on a low-toned bell and the
score of the opponents following on
a bell of higher pitch. If the team
meets defeat,"Home, Sweet Home"
is rendered by the chime ringer.
* * *
Students at Dartmouth have cleverly evaded the ruling of the Interstate Commerce Commission which
threatened to prevent them from
going to football games as "live
stock" in freight cars. They put a
pig in each car and the students go
along as caretakers.
* * *
Mr. Fritz Kellerman, a former
profeSsor at the University of Kansas, has been given the iron cross
for bravery in battle at BrestLitowsk, Russia.

of Virginia. This is the largest

institution. '

nines that could be put forth by

The game with Haverford next
Saturday will be a hard struggle
and should put the team on edge
for the deciding-games with St.
John's and Maryland Agricultural
College. Our schedule this year
has proved a hard one, in that Hopkins seems to be everybody's big
game, while the efforts of Mr.
Brennick and myself have been to
make St. John's and Maryland Agricultural College the objective
points of the season and to try to
develop the team accordingly. We
have been unfortunate in the number of men who are unable to play
for one reason or another, but all
the men on the squad realize what
is before them and each one is resolved to do his very best during
these last few days to help to bring
the team to its highest powers of

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 8, 1915.
WHO'S WHO IN FOOTBALL

A List of Players on This Year's Squad,
With Short Biography of Each
Man's Football Experience.

The University is fortunate this
year in having a large number of
experienced football men on the
squad. The following is a list of
the members of the squad, with
their positions and experience:
Aubrey comes from the University of Texas, where he played
guard for two years.
Barclay has played a guard position at Hopkins for three years and
is considered one of the best men in
the State at this position.
Bagley played in the backfield at
Tome School and has played for
two years at Hopkins.
Benson is playing his first year
of football.
Bowers was quarterback on the
Western Maryland team for two
years and has played one year at
Hopkins, making the all-Maryland
team.
Joe Branham played in the backfield on the Washington College
team before coming to Hopkins last
year.
Jack Branham has had three
years' experience as a Hopkins
halfback.
Brooks has played one year at
Hopkins.
Brumbaugh comes from Western
Maryland, where he played two
years.
Connolly conies from Towson
High School and played on last
year's freshman team.
Cort played last year on the
freshman team.
Cox is an experienced man, coming from the Shenandoah Military
Institute.
R. Cox played at fullback position on the Baltimore City College
team.
Darley has had a year of quarterback experience at Hopkins.
Duncan was a backfield man on
last year's freshman team, coming
from Towson High School.
Ellicott had two years' experience as a back on Gilman School's
team.
F. Ewing played last year at
Hopkins in an end position.
L. Ewing has never played before this season.
Elmendorf was Rutger's captain
and quarterback last year, being a
second all-American choice.
Finney was a member of Princeton's football squad for two years,
playing end.
Frank has had Hopkins experience for two years.
Frock was a substitute halfback
on Michigan's team last year.
Fulton played on the City College eleven for two years and on
Hopkins for one year.
Gorman's experience at the game
is the same as Fulton's.
Golden is a candidate for a
guard position, having played on
last year's freshman team.

Hall has had two year's experience on the Hopkins squad.
Hoffman played last year in the
fullback position at Hopkins, being
an all-Maryland choice.
Kauffman is an experienced
guard from Franklin and Marshall.
Kefover is a heavy man from St.
James' School, where he played
three years.
Kirk was end on last year's
Marston's team.
Martindale is going through his
first year at football.
Ormond was center on Princeton
for two years and is a fast, aggressive man.
Captain Primrose played at City
College and has been 'Varsity center at Hopkins for three years.
Randall had two years of football at Gilman and one at Hopkins.
Richards has had a year's experience at Hopkins.
Sachs is an experienced back
from Gettysburg College.
Schmidt was Polytechnic's mainstay in the line last year.
Smith is a new man at the
game.
Sonneborn is a big man from last
year's Park School team.
Stanley has had two years' experience at Dunham's.
Strom never played before, but
is rapidly developing.
Prince also has never played before.
Uhler has been a regular backfield man at Hopkins for three
years. He played at City College.
Webb has played three years at
Jefferson School.
Wessels is having his first try
at football.
Wilkinson was last year's captain
and has been the backbone of the
line for the past two years.
Woodward has had one year of
experience at City College and one
at Hopkins.
Yewell played for two years at
Dunham's and was one of last
year's regular guards.

Coach Brickley a Shot-Putter.

Although it is not generally
known, Coach Brickley has been
something of a shot-putter in his
day. He walked over to the pit
where several Hopkins men were
throwing the twelve-pound shot one
afternoon not long ago and surprised everyone by picking up a
twelve pounder and, with no apparent effort, throwing it nearly
forty-five feet. He further surprised everyone by saying that his
record for the sixteen-pound shot
was forty-four feet, which beats
the Hopkins record. He made several creditable throws with a sixteen pounder before returning to
his football team.

Freshman Bible Class Organizes.

The Freshman Bible Study Class
held its first meeting last Tuesday.
C. P. McCormick was chosen president and R. C. Thomsen, secretary.
The class, which will take up the
course of "Student Standards of
Action," will meet every Tuesday
at i P. M. and will be led by Mr.
J. W. Moore. All freshmen are
invited.

"X. Y. Z." Defends Freshmen.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LErrER :

UNIVERSITY DIRECTORY

Sir—I wish to disagree with the
sentiments expressed by "i8" in
his letter published in last week's
NEWS - LETTER. The sophomore
who wrote it seems to consider the
Freshman Class a mob of unruly
"toughs," who can only be tamed
by the most severe hazing tactics.
I think the rest of the school will
agree with me that the freshmen
are not of this type, but are sensible enough to see the value of
the regulations and to obey them.
If some first-year man inadvertently
neglected to remove his hat on first
entering McCoy Hall or broke the
rules in some other trifling way,
the sophomore who raved so in
last week's NEWS-LETTER apparently took it that the whole '19
Class was deliberately defying the
rules and challenging the sophomores to a free-for-all.
Such is not the case. If the
sophomores will keep their heads
they will see that the freshmen are
doing all in their power toward
making the plan of having freshman regulations a success.
The rules were a new thing to
the freshmen and any slight infringements should be overlooked
at first. The Class of '18 should
not abandon the plans for a peaceful settlement of the differences between the first and second years,
nor should they lose confidence in
the ability of the Student Council
to handle the affair in the best way,
both for the students and the University. The freshmen are doing
their part; let the sophomores remember what their part really is
and not do otherwise.
X. Y. Z.
November 6, 1915.

The municipal problem is not only
modern, but is in a large degree
peculiar to each city. "The peculiarity depends upon the general social and economic conditions of the
country in which the city is located; upon the geographical position of the city; upon the population and local conditions of the
city. No attempt to solve the problems of a particular city," Dr.
Goodnow continued, "which does
not take into account its peculiar
conditions will be successful. Many
suggestions May be- derived from
a consideration of the conditions
of other cities, but any attempt to
adopt in a wholesale manner ,instir
tutions which have met with success under other conditions is liable
to be followed by a very small
measure of success or even by positive failure."
Dr. Goodnow next discussed the
evolution of the form of municipal
government during the last century.
He told of the original council system, adopted from England but
modified by universal suffrage,
where the council was elected, and
the mayor also, unless appointed by
the governor. Its development into
the board system was traced, with
its dissipation of responsibility and
denial of popular control. Later
there came, said Dr. Goodnow, the
period in which the power of the
mayor was expanded greatly, which
tended toward a larger concentration of power. The main objection to the "mayor system" is its
tendency to dislocate the entire municipal government at every mayoralty election.
The most recent form of city
government is that which lodges the
power in a commission of five elected
members, each of whom has under.
his control some particular branch of
the administration. Substantially,
this is the old "council system." It
is significant, Dr. Goodnow observed, that after a century of
change America should return to
the council system, 'to which Great
Britain has adhered all the while
with success. "Good city government," Dr. Goodnow concluded,
"will result from the successful
adaptation of municipal institutions
to local conditions."

The artist was painting—sunset,
red, with blue streaks and green
dots. The old rustic, at a respectful distance, was watching.
"Ah," said the artist, looking up
suddenly, "perhaps to you, too, nature has opened her sky-pictures
page by page? Have you seen the
lambent flame of dawn leaping
across the livid East; the redstained, sulphurous islets floating iri
the lake of fire in the West; the
ragged clouds at midnight, black as
raven's wing, blotting out the shuddering moon?"
"No," replied the rustic shortly,
"not since I signed the pledge."

Shortly after the opening of the
second half came Gettysburg's lone
touchdown. Rowe caught a punt
on his own 45-yard line and by
clever dodging carried the ball fiftyfive Tards for a touchdown. Stoney
kicked goal.
Hopkins rooters were now much
depressed with the score against
them. However, it was shortly
after this that Hoffman kicked his
third field goal, making the score
9 to 7 in favor of Hopkins.
In the fourth quarter Gettysburg proved easy, Hopkins scoring
two touchdowns during that period.
The first was due to the excellent
line plunging of Brooks and the
headwork of Bowers, while the second was made by Eggie Gorman,
who recovered a punt which Rowe
fumbled on his own 3-yard line.
Wilkinson kicked goal on both occasions.
